oracle.mapviewer.share
Class RenderingRule

java.lang.Object
  oracle.mapviewer.share.RenderingRule

public class RenderingRule
extends java.lang.Object

RenderingRule represents an advanced definition or rule for using styles when rendering a theme's features. It can be used in two different scenarios:
1) For advanced styles: A base advanced style associated with some attributes (columns) can have its rendering affected by some other attributes via a sub-style. For instance, you can have an ADVANCED style that displays markers of different sizes based on one value column, while uses another column to change the fill color of those displayed markers thourhg a secondary color style.
2) When multiple RenderingRules are specified on a theme, MapViewer applies multiple styles to its features in a single rendering pass. You can even assign different value columns for each style.
The following example (in its XML equivalent) illustrates both scenarios, where the first rendering rule is used for scenario 1, and both rules combine for scenario 2. 


  <styling_rules >
  <rule column="TOTPOP" >
    <features style="V.MARKERS"> pop < 1000000 </features>
   <label column="STATE" style="T.CITY NAME"> 1 </label>
   <rendering>
      <style name="V.GRADUAL MARKERS" value_columns="damage">
             <substyle name="V.COLORS" value_columns="site_type" changes="FILL_COLOR" />
      </style>
      <style name="V.PIE CHART" value_columns="asian, black, latin, white, native" />
   </rendering>
  </rule>
  </styling_rules>
Note however you will typically create the kind of rendering rules show above for a theme using the Map Builder tool. This class is only useful when you are creating a custom Non-Spatial Data Provider implementation and would like to tell MapViewer which value columns from your provider should be rendered using which style.

See Also:
NSDataSet

public void setSubStyleName(java.lang.String name)
Sets the secondary style name. A secondary style is used to influence certain visual aspects of the main style being applied in the usage scenario 1 described above.

Parameters:
name - - sub-style name
